ResourceHeader.Description: NASA's IBEX (Interstellar Boundary Explorer) spacecraft was launched 19-Oct-2008 to discover the interaction between the solar wind and the interstellar medium. Its two energetic neutral atom (ENA) instruments measure 10 eV - 6 keV ENA's indicative of charged particle populations near and beyond the heliosphere's termination shock. The spacecraft is in a geocentric, 8-day orbit between 7000 km and 37 Re. Its spin axis is adjusted each orbit to point towards the sun. Its two ENA detectors look normal to the spin axis, thus measuring 360 deg swaths of the sky each 15-sec spacecraft spin. The full sky is measured every 6 months.

InformationURL.Name: IBEX web pages at SWRI
InformationURL.Description: Section of overall IBEX pages at SWRI for researchers, with links to published descriptive and science-results papers

InformationURL.Name: Space Science Reviews paper
InformationURL.Description: Paper is by D.J. McComas and 28 co-authors.

ResourceHeader.Description: The IBEX-Hi instrument measures ENA's in six energy bands within the 0.38-6.0 keV range. The instrument is a single-pixel imager with a 6.5 x 6.5 deg field of view that images a 6.5 x 360 swath of the sky each 15-sec spacecraft spin about the sun-pointing spin axis. The six energy windows have FWHM ranges of 0.38-0.59, 0.52-0.95, 0.84-1.55, 1.36-2.50, 1.99-3.75, 3.13-6.00 keV. These are referred to as bands 1 to 6, respectively, in data products. In normal operation, 2 successive spins are devoted to each energy window every 12 spin (~3 min) periods.

InformationURL.Name: Space Science Reviews paper
InformationURL.Description: Paper is by H.O. Funsten and 34 co-authors.

ResourceHeader.Description: Interstellar Boundary Explorer, IBEX, Spacecraft Ephemeris: The NASA Interstellar Boundary Explorer, IBEX, spacecraft was launched on October 19, 2008 to discover the interaction between the solar wind and the interstellar medium. Its two energetic neutral atom, ENA, instruments measure 10 eV to 6 keV ENAs indicative of charged particle populations near and beyond the heliospheric termination shock. The spacecraft is in a geocentric, 8-day orbit between 7000 km and 37 Re. Its spin axis is adjusted each orbit to point towards the sun. Its two ENA detectors look normal to the spin axis, thus measuring 360° swaths of the sky each 15 s spacecraft spin. The full sky is measured every 6 months.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: Please acknowledge the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, NASA, and the IBEX Mission Principal Investigator, David J. McComas, Princeton University.

Instrument.InvestigationName: Interstellar Boundary Explorer, IBEX, Spacecraft Ephemeris

OperatingSpan.Note: Interstellar Boundary Explorer, IBEX, launch date and time

ResourceHeader.Description: The IBEX Background Monitor (IBaM) measures the flux of >~14 keV protons at 0.24s time resolution in a 7-deg (FWHM) conical viewing angle. IBaM is housed with, and coaligned (normal to the IBEX spin axis) with, the IBEX-Hi instrument. The IBEX spin period is ~15 sec. IBaM and IBEX-Hi use identical detectors (channel-electron multipliers) and share a similar electronics design. See Sp.Sci.Rev. (2009) 146:105-115.

InformationURL.Name: Space Science Reviews paper
InformationURL.Description: Paper is by F. Allegrini and nine co-authors.

ResourceHeader.Description: The IBEX-Lo instrument measures ENA's in eight energy bands within the 0.01-2.0 keV range. The instrument is a single-pixel imager with a 7x7 deg field of view (FOV) in three 90 deg quadrants and a 3.5 x 3.5 deg FOV in a fourth, "high resolution" quadrant. The eight energy windows overlap and have center energies of 14, 27, 52, 102, 197, 451, 908 and 1903 eV. These are referred to as bands 1 to 8, respectively, in data products. The instrumentation includes a triple- coincidence time-of-flight mass spectrometer to help distinguish between heliospheric hydrogen and interstellar oxygen and helium. The instrument images full 360 deg swaths of the sky each 15-sec spacecraft spin about the sun-pointing spin axis. In normal operation, two successive spins are devoted to each energy window every 16 spin (~4 min) periods.

InformationURL.Name: Space Science Reviews paper
InformationURL.Description: Paper is by S.A. Fusilier and 47 co-authors.
